author: By Rachel Fabi
title: The Way I See It
description: Get back together with Kathy Lowden’s Monday puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — The constructor of today’s puzzle, Kathy Lowden, is making her second appearance in the New York Times Crossword today, after debuting in a 2020 collaboration with her daughter. It’s a welcome return — Ms. Lowden’s puzzle is a perfectly executed example of what an associate puzzle editor, Tracy Bennett, calls a “sum of the parts” theme, in which “one part of a multiword phrase is in a category that’s revealed punnily in a final entry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Senate Passes Climate, Health and Tax Bill, With All Republicans Opposed
description: The vote was a major victory for President Biden and Democrats, who are battling to maintain their slim House and Senate majorities in November’s midterm congressional elections.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate passed legislation on Sunday that would make the most significant federal investment in history to counter climate change and lower the cost of prescription drugs, as Democrats banded together to push through major pieces of President Biden’s domestic agenda over unified Republican opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Here’s How Democrats’ Big Domestic Agenda Bill Has Shrunk
description: The legislation was a major victory for President Biden and Democrats, but a shadow of the transformative, multitrillion-dollar plan they proposed last year.
content: WASHINGTON — The sweeping climate change, health care and tax package that is on track to clear Congress this week is a major victory for President Biden and Democrats in Congress, who toiled for months to salvage as much as they could of a domestic agenda that met with solid Republican opposition and resistance from within their own ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Lisa Friedman
title: What’s in the Climate, Tax and Health Care Package
description: The bill includes billions in tax credits for the production of renewable energy, drug-pricing reforms and a boost for the I.R.S.
content: WASHINGTON — After months of painstaking negotiations, Democrats are set to push through a climate, tax and health care package that would salvage key elements of President Biden’s domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Chuck Schumer, the ‘Happy Worrier,’ Delivers
description: The Senate majority leader managed to resurrect and pass a signature climate change and health care deal with help from Republican missteps.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer was huddled in his Capitol office on Thursday evening awaiting a climactic meeting with Kyrsten Sinema, a critical holdout on his painstakingly negotiated climate change, tax and health care deal, when the loud booms and flashes of a powerful thunderstorm shook Washington, setting the lights flickering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats hold off Republican amendments, and some of their own.
description: Republicans railed against climate spending and an $80 billion plan to beef up tax enforcement at the I.R.S.
content: For Republicans, the hourslong ritual of the vote-a-rama served as a last-ditch effort to inflict political pain over a package they have no intention of supporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. Senate Passes Major Legislation
description: Also, China’s military exercises could alienate Taiwan and rockets strike near a Ukrainian nuclear power plant.
content: Congress edged closer to realizing a slew of Democratic priorities when the Senate passed the climate and tax bill after an all-night legislative bender known as a vote-a-rama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Is an Uneasy Champion on Abortion. Can He Lead the Fight in Post-Roe America?
description: A practicing Catholic, President Biden has long sought a middle ground on abortion. But activists see the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade as a sign that Democrats have tiptoed too carefully around the issue.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision to end the constitutional right to an abortion in the United States after nearly 50 years has set in motion a generational struggle over Republican efforts to ban the procedure in states across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra and Vimal Patel
title: Killings of 4 Men in Albuquerque Leave Muslim Community in Fear
description: As the authorities appeal to the public for help in their investigation, many Muslim residents are experiencing a “managed panic.”
content: Muhammad Imtiaz Hussain is afraid to step outside his home in Albuquerque to water his plants. Or retrieve books from his car. Or even venture out onto his balcony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and John Liu
title: After China’s Military Spectacle, Options Narrow for Winning Over Taiwan
description: The exercises were designed to deter Taiwan from moving further away from Beijing, but they also indicated how few policy carrots China has.
content: China’s 72-hour spectacle of missiles, warships and jet fighters swarming Taiwan was designed to create a firewall — a blazing, made-for-television warning against what Beijing sees as increasingly stubborn defiance, backed by Washington, of its claims to the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: A U.S. Return to Guadalcanal, in Another Tense Historical Moment
description: At a ceremony to mark the 80th anniversary of a crucial battle in the Pacific, two daughters of men who served there reflected on the lessons of war.
content: Caroline Kennedy, the United States ambassador to Australia, and Wendy Sherman, the U.S. deputy secretary of state, stood together at dawn on Sunday on the island of Guadalcanal to honor the 80th anniversary of the World War II battle there that nearly led to the deaths of their fathers, and that redefined America’s role across Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: A Revolution Behind the Curtain
description: A new series of essays captures American theater as it attempts to reject some of its foundational inequities.
content: Forty years ago, Jesse Green, then a recent college graduate with a degree in English and theater, was a general assistant at the Williamstown Theater Festival. He made waffles, cleaned toilets and performed other work, all of it unpaid and “some of it unsafe and some of it degrading,” he wrote later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saru Jayaraman
title: Hulu’s ‘The Bear’ and the Restaurant Industry’s Long Overdue Reckoning
description: The Hulu drama is resonating partly because it shows workers demanding a better workplace, which is happening in the restaurant industry and beyond.
content: This article contains spoilers for the Hulu series “The Bear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jared Beasley
title: 72-Year-Old Runner Will Not Let This Endurance Race Go
description: Marge Hickman is the most frequent female finisher in the Leadville Trail 100-mile race. She hasn’t finished in more than a decade, but she’s lining up again.
content: LEADVILLE, Colo. — In the crisp predawn hours last August, 71-year-old Marge Hickman slipped the brace off her sprained ankle and eased to the starting line of the Leadville Trail 100-mile race. Part of her said go home. The race wasn’t what it used to be. She didn’t feel wanted anyway. She loved this race. She hated this race. She revolved her entire life around this race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Manchin’s Donors Include Pipeline Giants That Win in His Climate Deal
description: The controversial Mountain Valley Pipeline is one of several projects the senator has negotiated major concessions for, benefiting his financial supporters.
content: BLACKSBURG, Va. — After years of spirited opposition from environmental activists, the Mountain Valley Pipeline — a 304-mile gas pipeline cutting through the Appalachian Mountains — was behind schedule, over budget and beset with lawsuits. As recently as February, one of its developers, NextEra Energy, warned that the many legal and regulatory obstacles meant there was “a very low probability of pipeline completion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: After Rockets Strike Near Nuclear Plant, Ukraine and Russia Trade Blame
description: Moscow accused Ukraine of striking near spent-fuel storage at the Zaporizhzhia power plant, while Ukrainian intelligence said it was a move by Russia to destroy infrastructure.
content: Ukraine accused Russian forces on Sunday of imperiling a captured nuclear power plant, saying that a catastrophic radiation leak was “miraculously avoided” after rockets landed on the complex’s grounds. It was the latest threat to Europe’s largest nuclear facility, where fighting in the southern region has prompted fears of a major accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Blistering Job Growth
description: Elon Musk countersues Twitter. The Walt Disney Company’s bold subscriber ambitions may get a check in its quarterly earnings report. And the latest inflation number comes out.
content: Analysts had forecast an increase of 250,000 jobs in July. And so it was a shock when the Department of Labor’s report showed that more than twice that number — 528,000 —  were added last month. The blistering pace of growth brought total employment back to prepandemic levels, a befuddling benchmark considering other recent signs of a slowing economy, including a falling gross domestic product and a more sedate housing market. Indeed, this latest jobs report provides more questions than answers about the state of the U.S. economy: What is the cause of employers’ confidence in hiring if many fear a recession? Why is the job market so resilient if the economy seems to be more depressed? These are apparent contradictions that Federal Reserve officials will weigh as they think about what path to take.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Republicans force the removal of a measure that would cap insulin prices at $35 for private insurers.
description: The cap for private insurers was widely viewed as a violation of the strict budgetary rules that govern the reconciliation process Democrats are using to fast-track the package.
content: Senate Republicans on Sunday forced the removal of a Democratic proposal that would have capped insulin prices at $35 for private insurers, even as seven Republicans joined all 50 members of the Democratic caucus in an effort to preserve the provision in the climate, tax and health care spending bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: A New ‘Ring’ at Bayreuth Does Wagner Without Magic
description: Valentin Schwarz’s production of the four-opera epic presents human characters with relations even more tangled than usual.
content: BAYREUTH, Germany — About 150 years ago, in a megalomaniac’s coup, Richard Wagner built a theater on a hilltop here in northern Bavaria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Some Women ‘Self-Manage’ Abortions as Access Recedes
description: Information and medications needed to end a pregnancy are increasingly available outside the health care system.
content: In states that have banned abortion, some women with unwanted pregnancies are pursuing an unconventional workaround: They are “self-managing” their abortions, seeking out the necessary know-how online and obtaining the medications without the supervision of a clinic or a doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Biden’s Remarkable Summer
description: The president needs to seize this moment and brag about his wins.
content: Media narratives are driven by trajectory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Consumers will benefit from lower utility bills and cheaper home upgrades, energy experts say.
description: The Inflation Reduction Act includes tax deductions for energy-efficient home upgrades and a tax credit for electric vehicles.
content: The Inflation Reduction Act that was passed by the Senate on Sunday could lower electricity bills for consumers and the prices of things like rooftop solar panels, energy-efficient appliances and electric vehicles, Democrats and some energy experts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Demaryius Thomas’s Death Was Caused by Seizure Disorder
description: The former N.F.L. receiver died at 33, six months after he retired from football. He had been posthumously diagnosed with chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E.
content: Demaryius Thomas, a four-time All-Pro receiver with the Denver Broncos, died of complications from seizures, the medical examiner in Fulton County, Ga., said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Travel Troubles
description: Two Times reporters answered your travel questions to help you navigate this hectic vacation season.
content: For many travelers, cancellations and other snags have made this summer especially frustrating. To help you understand how we got here and how to make the most of your own trips, two Times travel experts — Niraj Chokshi, who covers transportation, and Heather Murphy, who reports on how people travel — answered reader questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Mediators make progress toward a cease-fire, diplomats say.
description: Egyptian mediators made progress on Sunday toward a cease-fire between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza, three officials briefed on negotiations said, raising hopes that the latest outbreak of hostilities might end by early Monday.
content: Egyptian mediators made progress on Sunday toward a cease-fire between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza, three officials briefed on negotiations said, raising hopes that the latest outbreak of hostilities might end by early Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Will the bill curb inflation? Democrats think it will, but not immediately.
description: A Congressional Budget Office analysis found that the measure would have little effect on inflation this year. Democrats argue the benefits will still be felt.
content: The estimated effect of the Senate’s climate and tax bill on inflation was among the many points Democrats defended on Saturday night and into Sunday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Oyler
title: Even the Idea of Motherhood Is Lonely
description: In “Diary of a Void,” Emi Yagi unravels the limitless ironies of maternity.
content: Blame it on social media, on synoptic attention spans, whatever: The speculative conceit reigns in contemporary publishing, where few novels live up to their promise of revelatory social commentary. But a particularly good one can still tempt even the most cynical of readers. In the Japanese author Emi Yagi’s prizewinning debut, “Diary of a Void,” a single woman in her mid-30s, frustrated by her stupefying job at a company that manufactures cardboard cores for paper products, spontaneously decides to feign pregnancy in order to get out of menial tasks like making coffee and cleaning up after meetings — the stench of unappreciated labor aggravates her morning sickness. Over the course of the novel, she carries the lie to term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Clu Gulager, Rugged Character Actor of Film and TV, Dies at 93
description: On TV, he played Billy the Kid on the “The Tall Man” and was seen on the long-running “The Virginian.” His movies ranged from “The Killers” to “The Last Picture Show.”
content: Clu Gulager, a rugged character actor who appeared in critically acclaimed films like “The Last Picture Show” as well as low-budget horror movies, and who memorably portrayed gunslingers on two television westerns, died on Friday at his son John’s home in Los Angeles. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Jouhari
title: Greetings From My Shameless Summer
description: Wear the crop top. Have the salad — and the fries, too.
content: I live for moments when I feel encyclopedic. Yesterday, at a backyard party, people asked who sang the song that was playing and I screamed out “Keyshia Cole” with a little too much enthusiasm. I was right, and I lit up with such delight that I felt stupid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Senate Holds All-Night ‘Vote-a-Rama,’ With Democrats’ Agenda at Stake
description: Bleary-eyed senators went through a marathon series of votes at the Capitol that was the final step before passing Democrats’ climate, energy and tax package.
content: WASHINGTON — A bleary-eyed Senator Joe Manchin III, the West Virginia Democrat who brokered the climate, health and tax deal that was on a glide path to passage within hours, sat silently at his desk in the Senate chamber around midnight on Saturday, gazing blankly into the middle distance as he munched on M&Ms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: They Made History at Alabama. But Football Stardom Had a Price.
description: At least four fixtures of Alabama’s great teams of the 1960s had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., at their deaths. Researchers expect it in other players, too.
content: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Near the end, his brain deteriorated after almost a lifetime around football, Ray Perkins was still captivated by the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Four more grain ships leave Ukrainian ports.
description: The ships, the largest caravan to depart Ukraine since the Russian invasion began, were headed for China, Iran, Italy and Turkey.
content: The biggest caravan of ships carrying grain and other agricultural products since the beginning of the Russian invasion has sailed from Ukrainian ports on Sunday, heading to Europe, Asia and the Middle East through the mined waters of the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Why Is Ron Johnson Still Competitive Despite, You Know, Everything?
description: He has a way of winning Wisconsin Senate races in spite of his weird behavior. Democrats see ousting him this fall as key to keeping the Senate.
content: Of all the political quandaries and questions of the 2022 midterms, one burns especially bright: How is it that Senator Ron Johnson, the two-term Republican from Wisconsin, remains a remotely viable candidate for re-election?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Checking Out the Crowd
description: Notable outfits from the Watermill Center’s benefit, a Louis Vuitton party and the ACE Awards.
content: Hamptons parties are not confined to weekends. Louis Vuitton held a Thursday cocktail party at Le Bilboquet in Sag Harbor, N.Y., to celebrate its latest “savoir-faire studio”: a collection of fine furniture, trunks, jewelry and other objects displayed in a modern residence on nearby Shelter Island. Needless to say, many guests wore Louis Vuitton.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Surprised, I Turned to See an Older Man There on the Sidewalk’
description: Getting advice on birthday bouquets, at a deli in Greenpoint and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: We Went on a Lanternfly-Killing Rampage. They’re Still Here.
description: The spotted lanternfly, an invasive pest that ecologists have urged the populace to squish on sight, is back, infesting the New York City area.
content: Last week, a pretty moth on a flower outside a window caught this reporter’s eye. Closer inspection confirmed suspicion: It was a spotted lanternfly, an invasive insect that New Yorkers are under scientists’ orders to kill without mercy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: An Afro-Colombian Aesthetic Rises to the Presidential Palace
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 7, 2022
content: “To wear this every day, not as ‘fashion,’ not to dress up for a special occasion, but as a way of life, as something you want to communicate every day — yes, it is political. And, yes, it is a symbol of resistance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
title: Five Decades in the Making: Why It Took Congress So Long to Act on Climate
description: The Senate bill avoided the political pitfalls of past legislative attempts by offering only incentives to cut climate pollution, not taxes.
content: WASHINGTON — In 1969, President Richard Nixon’s adviser Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote a memo describing a startling future. The increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere caused by burning oil, gas and coal, Mr. Moynihan wrote, would dangerously heat the planet, melt the glaciers and cause the seas to rise. “Goodbye New York,” Mr. Moynihan wrote. “Goodbye Washington, for that matter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: A Model for an Evangelical Christianity Committed to Justice
description: His 1978 book, “Rich Christians in an Age of Hunger,” helped me through a crisis of faith.
content: In my first couple years of college I had a minor crisis of faith. I had grown up going to a large Southern church that prided itself on preaching the gospel, but leaders there did not talk much about systemic injustice or economic disparity. I was taking a class on poverty in the United States and another course taught by an avowed socialist passionately committed to radical politics. I was volunteering with a ministry that worked with undocumented immigrants and among the economically disadvantaged. I felt increasingly disconnected from my evangelical community on issues of nonviolence and social and economic justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Christopher Meyer, Vocal British Envoy to the U.S., Dies at 78
description: He served loyally during the 9/11 attacks and Iraq invasion. But in a 2005 memoir, he faulted the “conception and execution” of the Iraq war.
content: Christopher Meyer, the debonair diplomat who served as Britain’s ambassador to Washington from 1997 to 2003 but later argued that his government let itself be suckered into supporting the American invasion of Iraq, died on July 27 at his holiday home in Megeve, in the French Alps. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: New Jersey Man Gets 5 Years in Prison in GoFundMe Fraud Case
description: Prosecutors said Mark D’Amico and his then-girlfriend made up a heartwarming tale of a homeless man to help raise more than $400,000.
content: Mark D’Amico and his girlfriend said they wanted to reward a homeless man who had spent his last $20 to help her after she ran out of gas on a highway in Philadelphia in November 2017. The couple started a GoFundMe campaign that sought $10,000 to provide rent, a reliable vehicle and some living expenses for the man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘Jewel in the Crown of Corruption’: The Troubles of Kenya’s China-Funded Train
description: Five years after its launch, the railway has become associated with debt, dysfunction and criminal inquiries, and it is now a lightning rod in Tuesday’s election.
content: MOMBASA, Kenya — Fireworks popped and confetti rained down in the seaside city of Mombasa when Kenya’s president inaugurated the country’s new railway — designed, funded and built by China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel and Palestinian Militants Reach a Cease-Fire
description: The truce appeared to end a three-day conflict in Gaza that barely changed the status quo in Israel and the occupied territories, but  revealed splits among rival Palestinian militias.
content: Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza agreed to a cease-fire late on Sunday night, in a move that was expected to end a three-day conflict that killed dozens of Palestinians, including militant commanders, but which did little to change the status quo in Israel and the occupied territories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Fighting around a Ukrainian nuclear plant heightens safety fears.
description: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Fighting raged on Saturday near a sprawling nuclear power plant in the south of Ukraine, despite warnings from nuclear safety watchdogs earlier this week that conditions there were posing risks and “out of control.”
content: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Fighting raged on Saturday near a sprawling nuclear power plant in the south of Ukraine, despite warnings from nuclear safety watchdogs earlier this week that conditions there were posing risks and “out of control.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: In Defense of ‘Diana,’ the Show We Didn’t Deserve
description: On the eve of a concert with three of the flop musical’s talented stars, time to celebrate a production that thrilled loyal fans — and at least one critic.
content: Broadway’s comeback season was a hurricane. Not even the heavily awarded revival of a Sondheim favorite like “Company” could withstand shaky ticket sales brought on by a pandemic-wary theatergoing community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Emerges From Isolation Again After Second Negative Coronavirus Test
description: President Biden flew to Rehoboth Beach in Delaware for a brief day of relaxation after a rebound case of Covid-19.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden left isolation on Sunday morning after a weeklong rebound case of Covid-19, heading to Rehoboth Beach in Delaware for a short getaway before resuming official travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees Show Flaws and Get a First Look at Frankie Montas
description: The Yankees were swept in a three-game series for the first time this season and extended their losing streak to a season-worst five games.
content: ST. LOUIS — Slipping of late but still holding a slight edge for the best record in the American League, the Yankees took action last Monday ahead of the Major League Baseball trade deadline. They sent two of their top 10 prospects and two other minor league players to the Oakland Athletics in exchange for the relief pitcher Lou Trivino and the starting pitcher Frankie Montas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: I Didn’t Want It to Be True, but the Medium Really Is the Message
description: How we look matters as much as what we see.
content: In 2020, I read a book I’d been ignoring for 10 years, Nicholas Carr’s “The Shallows: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brains.” It was a finalist for a Pulitzer Prize in 2011 and much loved among people who seemed to hate the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Khaled Mansour, the slain militant commander, was behind a string of attacks, the Israeli military said.
description: The Islamic Jihad commander for southern Gaza was killed in an Israeli missile strike on Saturday.
content: Khaled Mansour, the Islamic Jihad militant commander who was killed in an Israeli missile strike in southern Gaza on Saturday night, was responsible for rocket and mortar attacks against Israel stretching back years, according to the Israeli military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker, Jack D'Isidoro, Marion Lozano, John Woo, Elisheba Ittoop and Zachary Mouton
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Why Was Joshua Held for More Than Two Years for Someone Else’s Crimes?’
description: Honolulu incarcerated the wrong man for more than two years — a miscarriage of justice that shows the cruel inadequacy of America’s approach to mental health.
content: The more he insisted that his name was Joshua, the more delusional he came to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Amnesty International Assessment That Ukraine ‘Put Civilians in Harm’s Way’ Stirs Outrage
description: The human rights group accused the Ukrainian military of establishing bases and weapons systems in schools and hospitals.
content: The director of Amnesty International’s Ukraine office resigned on Friday to protest a lengthy statement by the wider organization that accuses Ukrainian soldiers of employing tactics of war that endanger civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Liz Cheney Is Ready to Lose. But She’s Not Ready to Quit.
description: The Republican says her crusade to stop Donald J. Trump will continue — even if she loses her primary next week. Restoring a “very sick” G.O.P. will take years, she says, “if it can be healed.”
content: CHEYENNE, Wyo. — It was just over a month before her primary, but Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming was nowhere near the voters weighing her future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marco Hernandez
title: Maps: Tracking Tensions Between China and Taiwan
description: Maps showing where Chinese military aircraft and unmanned drones are flying close to Taiwan.
content: Maps showing where Chinese military aircraft and unmanned drones are flying close to Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make a plan for fish sticks with peas, summer pasta and more recipes.
content: Good morning. I had this idea that I was going to cook fish sticks with peas (above), on account of how excellent the recipe is. It retains the look and feel of a classic meal of my childhood, while allowing for adult tastes: turmeric in the fish batter for warmth and hue; mint, lemon zest and red pepper flakes in the peas for pop. (Make this outstanding tartar sauce to go with it.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 7, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 7, 2022.
content: An article on Page 9 this weekend about six podcasts centered on political scandals and upheaval refers incorrectly to the producers of “The Fault Line: Bush, Blair and Iraq.” They are Somethin’ Else and Sony Music Entertainment, not the BBC.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can a Third Party Succeed? Should It?
description: Debating the role of third parties in America. Also: The U.S. and the Taliban; perfecting propaganda; Alaska Natives and a fuel project.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
